description: From post-classical Latin diffusivus (“tending to spread; expansive”) (13th century), from participle stem of Latin diffundere (“diffuse, disperse”).

adjectives.description: diffusive (comparative more diffusive, superlative most diffusive)

entries.meaning: That is spread or dispersed across a wide area or among a large number of people. [from 17th c.]
Involving or employing many words; expansive, discursive; (in negative sense) long-winded. [from 17th c.]
examples: I can never forget the delight with which that diffusive and ingenious orator was heard by all sides of the House, and even by those whose existence he proscribed.
